hero.title: Discover Space Wonders
hero.subtitle: Embark on an interactive journey through the cosmos. Explore planets, galaxies, black holes and more with stunning visualizations and educational content.

planetExplorer.title: Interactive Solar System
planetExplorer.subtitle: Explore our solar system in 3D. Click on planets to learn fascinating facts about each celestial body.

spaceshipExplorer.title: Space Technology
spaceshipExplorer.subtitle: Explore 3D models of spacecraft and technology that has allowed us to explore the cosmos.

features.title: Cosmic Phenomena
features.subtitle: Dive deep into the most fascinating cosmic phenomena and learn about the wonders of our universe.
features.blackHolesDesc: Explore the mysterious regions of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape.
features.galaxiesDesc: Discover the vast systems of stars, stellar remnants, interstellar gas, dust, and dark matter.
features.nebulaeDesc: Witness the breathtaking interstellar clouds of gas and dust where stars are born and die.
features.exoplanetsDesc: Learn about planets that orbit stars outside our solar system and their potential for life.
features.missionsDesc: Follow humanity's journey to the stars through past, present, and future space missions.
features.technologyDesc: Explore the cutting-edge technology that makes space exploration possible.

timeline.title: Space Exploration Timeline
timeline.subtitle: COSMIC MILESTONES
timeline.description: Journey through the most significant moments in humanity's quest to explore the cosmos.

sputnik.title: Sputnik 1 Launch
sputnik.description: The Soviet Union launches Sputnik 1, the first artificial Earth satellite, marking the beginning of the Space Age.

laika.title: Laika: First Living Being in Orbit
laika.description: Laika, a stray dog from Moscow, became the first animal to orbit the Earth aboard the Soviet Sputnik 2, a crucial step for future manned spaceflights.

gagarin.title: First Human in Space
gagarin.description: Yuri Gagarin becomes the first human to journey into outer space, completing one orbit around Earth.

moonLanding.title: Apollo 11 Moon Landing
moonLanding.description: Neil Armstrong becomes the first person to step onto the lunar surface, marking a giant leap for mankind.

hubble.title: Hubble Space Telescope
hubble.description: NASA launches the Hubble Space Telescope, revolutionizing astronomy with its detailed images of deep space.

pluto.title: New Horizons Reaches Pluto
pluto.description: NASA's New Horizons spacecraft completes the first flyby of Pluto, providing unprecedented images of the dwarf planet.

blackHole.title: First Black Hole Image
blackHole.description: The Event Horizon Telescope team releases the first direct image of a black hole at the center of galaxy M87.

jamesWebb.title: James Webb Space Telescope
jamesWebb.description: The most powerful space telescope ever built begins operations, providing unprecedented views of the universe.

timeline.learnMoreDesc: On this website, you'll learn about planets, galaxies, black holes, and much more. Explore our interactive sections and discover the wonders of the cosmos.

solarSystem.title: Our Solar System
solarSystem.subtitle: Explore the planets, moons, asteroids, and comets that orbit our Sun.
solarSystem.exploreSubtitle: Explore the solar system in 3D from desktop or tablet.
solarSystem.no3dMobile: The 3D visualization of the solar system is only available on desktop or tablet.
solarSystem.planetDetailsSubtitle: Learn fascinating facts about each planet in our solar system.

facts.title: Fascinating Solar System Facts
facts.subtitle: Discover interesting facts about our cosmic neighborhood.
facts.sunDesc: The Sun contains 99.86% of the mass in the Solar System and is about 109 times the diameter of Earth.
facts.ringsDesc: While Saturn's rings are the most famous, Jupiter, Uranus, and Neptune also have ring systems.
facts.dwarfPlanetsDesc: The Solar System has five recognized dwarf planets: Pluto, Ceres, Haumea, Makemake, and Eris.
facts.asteroidBeltDesc: The Asteroid Belt between Mars and Jupiter contains millions of asteroids, with Ceres being the largest.
facts.kuiperBeltDesc: Beyond Neptune lies the Kuiper Belt, a region of icy bodies including Pluto and many comets.
facts.moonsDesc: There are over 200 known moons in our Solar System, with Jupiter having the most at 79 confirmed moons.

galaxies.title: Galaxies: Islands of Stars
galaxies.subtitle: Explore the vast collections of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter that make up the universe.
galaxies.typesSubtitle: Galaxies come in various shapes and sizes, each with unique characteristics.
galaxies.spiralDesc: Characterized by a central bulge surrounded by spiral arms. Our Milky Way is a spiral galaxy.
galaxies.ellipticalDesc: Smooth, oval-shaped galaxies with little gas and dust. They contain mostly older stars.
galaxies.irregularDesc: Galaxies with no definite shape, often the result of gravitational interactions with other galaxies.
galaxies.milkyWaySubtitle: Interact with a 3D model of our home galaxy.
galaxies.milkyWayDesc: Our galaxy, the Milky Way, is a barred spiral galaxy containing over 100 billion stars.

milkyWayFacts.blackHole: Contains a supermassive black hole at its center called Sagittarius A*
milkyWayFacts.location: Our solar system is located about 27,000 light-years from the galactic center
milkyWayFacts.orbit: It takes about 225-250 million years for our solar system to complete one orbit around the galaxy

galaxies.famousSubtitle: Discover some of the most well-known galaxies in our universe.
galaxies.andromedaDesc: The closest spiral galaxy to the Milky Way, located about 2.5 million light-years away.
galaxies.triangulumDesc: The third-largest galaxy in our Local Group, with a diameter of about 60,000 light-years.
galaxies.whirlpoolDesc: A classic spiral galaxy interacting with a smaller companion galaxy, creating a stunning visual.
galaxies.sombreroDesc: Known for its bright nucleus and large central bulge, resembling a sombrero hat.
galaxies.collisionsSubtitle: When galaxies meet, spectacular cosmic events unfold over billions of years.
galaxies.futureDesc: In about 4.5 billion years, the Milky Way and Andromeda galaxies will collide, creating a new elliptical galaxy sometimes called 'Milkomeda.' This collision won't be destructive to individual stars due to the vast distances between them, but it will dramatically reshape both galaxies.
galaxies.collisionEffects: Galaxy collisions trigger intense star formation as gas clouds are compressed, and they can also activate dormant black holes, turning them into active galactic nuclei.
galaxies.nebulaeDesc: Witness the beautiful interstellar clouds of gas and dust where stars are born and die.

blackHoles.title: Black Holes: Cosmic Enigmas
blackHoles.subtitle: Explore the mysterious regions of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing can escape.
blackHoles.exploreSubtitle: Interact with a 3D model of a black hole and its accretion disk.
blackHoles.whatAreDesc1: Black holes are regions of spacetime where gravity is so strong that nothing, no particles or even electromagnetic radiation such as light, can escape from it.
blackHoles.whatAreDesc2: A black hole forms when a massive star collapses under its own gravity at the end of its life cycle. The gravitational collapse creates a singularity, a point of infinite density, surrounded by an event horizon, the boundary beyond which nothing can return.
blackHoles.whatAreDesc3: Despite their name, black holes are not empty spaces. They are incredibly dense masses compressed into a small space. The more mass that is contained in a given volume, the stronger the gravitational field at the surface of that volume.
blackHoles.videoSubtitle: Watch this informative video to learn more about these fascinating cosmic phenomena.
blackHoles.typesSubtitle: Black holes come in different sizes and have different origins.
blackHoles.stellarDesc: Formed by the gravitational collapse of a massive star. They have masses ranging from about 5 to several tens of solar masses.
blackHoles.intermediateDesc: These have masses between 100 and 100,000 solar masses. They may form from the merger of stellar black holes or from the collapse of massive star clusters.
blackHoles.supermassiveDesc: Found at the centers of most galaxies, including our Milky Way. They have masses ranging from millions to billions of solar masses.
blackHoles.horizonSubtitle: Understanding the key components of a black hole.
blackHoles.eventHorizonDesc1: The event horizon is the boundary defining the region of space around a black hole from which nothing (including light) can escape. Once a particle crosses the event horizon, it will inevitably be drawn into the black hole.
blackHoles.eventHorizonDesc2: The radius of the event horizon (called the Schwarzschild radius) depends on the mass of the black hole. For a non-rotating black hole, it is given by the formula:
blackHoles.eventHorizonDesc3: Where G is the gravitational constant, M is the mass of the black hole, and c is the speed of light.
blackHoles.singularityDesc1: At the center of a black hole lies what physicists call a gravitational singularity, a one-dimensional point which contains a huge mass in an infinitely small space.
blackHoles.singularityDesc2: At the singularity, spacetime curvature becomes infinite and the laws of physics as we know them cease to operate. Our current understanding of physics cannot describe what happens at or beyond the singularity.
blackHoles.singularityDesc3: According to Einstein's theory of general relativity, the singularity is inevitable once an object crosses the event horizon. However, quantum mechanics suggests that singularities may not actually exist in reality.
blackHoles.landmarkSubtitle: Recent breakthroughs in our understanding of black holes.
blackHoles.firstImage: First Image of a Black Hole (2019)
blackHoles.firstImageDesc1: In April 2019, the Event Horizon Telescope (EHT) collaboration released the first direct image of a black hole. The image shows the supermassive black hole at the center of galaxy M87, located 55 million light-years from Earth, with a mass 6.5 billion times that of our Sun.
blackHoles.firstImageDesc2: The image shows a bright ring formed as light bends in the intense gravity around a black hole that is 6.5 billion times more massive than the Sun. This ring surrounds a dark center, the black hole's shadow.
blackHoles.gravitationalWaves: Gravitational Waves from Black Hole Mergers
blackHoles.gravitationalWavesDesc1: In 2015, the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) detected gravitational waves for the first time. These waves were produced by the collision of two black holes, confirming a major prediction of Einstein's general theory of relativity.
blackHoles.gravitationalWavesDesc2: Since then, dozens of black hole mergers have been detected through gravitational waves, providing a new way to study these cosmic phenomena and test our understanding of gravity.

missions.title: Space Missions: Exploring the Cosmos
missions.subtitle: Discover humanity's journey beyond Earth through historic and future space exploration missions.
missions.historicSubtitle: Key milestones in humanity's exploration of space.
missions.apollo11Desc: The first manned mission to land on the Moon, with astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin becoming the first humans to walk on the lunar surface.
missions.voyagerDesc: Voyager 1 and 2 have explored the outer planets and are now in interstellar space, making them the most distant human-made objects.
missions.hubbleDesc: Revolutionized astronomy with its deep-field images of distant galaxies and detailed observations of cosmic phenomena.
missions.marsSubtitle: Missions to our neighboring planet Mars.
missions.roversDesc: A series of increasingly sophisticated rovers have explored the Martian surface:
missions.sojourner: Sojourner (1997): The first rover on Mars, part of the Mars Pathfinder mission.
missions.spirit: Spirit & Opportunity (2004): Twin rovers that greatly exceeded their planned 90-day missions.
missions.curiosity: Curiosity (2012): A car-sized rover exploring Gale Crater, still operational.
missions.perseverance: Perseverance (2021): The most advanced rover yet, searching for signs of ancient life.
missions.ingenuity: Ingenuity: The first aircraft to make a powered, controlled flight on another planet. Deployed from the Perseverance rover in 2021, this small helicopter has demonstrated that powered flight is possible in the thin Martian atmosphere.
missions.currentFutureSubtitle: Ongoing and planned missions pushing the boundaries of space exploration.
missions.jwstDesc: Launched in 2021, this next-generation space telescope is observing the universe in infrared, allowing it to look further back in time than ever before.
missions.artemisDesc: NASA's plan to return humans to the Moon by 2025, including the first woman and person of color, and establish sustainable lunar exploration.
missions.europaClipperDesc: Planned for launch in 2024, this mission will study Jupiter's moon Europa, which may harbor a subsurface ocean with conditions suitable for life.
missions.marsSampleReturnDesc: A series of missions to collect samples from Mars and return them to Earth for detailed analysis, working in conjunction with the Perseverance rover.
missions.davinciDesc: The Deep Atmosphere Venus Investigation of Noble gases, Chemistry, and Imaging mission will study Venus's atmosphere and surface.
missions.dragonflyDesc: A rotorcraft lander scheduled to launch in 2027 to explore Saturn's largest moon, Titan, which has an atmosphere and liquid methane lakes.
missions.privateSubtitle: Commercial enterprises revolutionizing access to space.
missions.spacexDesc1: Founded by Elon Musk, SpaceX has revolutionized space travel with reusable rockets like the Falcon 9 and Falcon Heavy. The company's Crew Dragon spacecraft now regularly transports astronauts to the International Space Station.
missions.spacexDesc2: Future plans include the Starship spacecraft, designed for missions to the Moon, Mars, and beyond, as well as the Starlink satellite constellation to provide global internet coverage.
missions.blueOriginDesc1: Founded by Jeff Bezos, Blue Origin is developing rockets for both suborbital and orbital spaceflight. Their New Shepard vehicle has successfully carried tourists to the edge of space.
missions.blueOriginDesc2: The company is also developing the New Glenn orbital rocket and the Blue Moon lunar lander, which could play a role in NASA's Artemis program to return humans to the Moon.

welcome.subtitle: Embark on a journey through the cosmos and discover the wonders of our universe.

kids.title: Space for Kids!
kids.subtitle: Explore the universe with fun!
kids.astroIntro: Hi! I'm Astro, your space guide. Join me on this cosmic adventure!
kids.planetsDesc: Touch the planets to learn about them!
kids.fact1Desc: Stars twinkle because their light passes through Earth's atmosphere!
kids.fact2Desc: There's no sound in space because there's no air for sound to travel through!
kids.fact3Desc: On the Moon, you can jump 6 times higher than on Earth!
kids.marsFact: Mars is called the Red Planet!
kids.jupiterFact: Jupiter has a big red spot!
kids.clickToLearn: Click me to learn fun facts!
kids.coloringDesc: Use your imagination to color these space drawings!
kids.constellationsDesc: Connect the stars to make pictures in the sky!
kids.alienDesc: Imagine what aliens from other planets might look like!
kids.constellationsInstructions: Click on stars to connect them and form constellations!
kids.constellationComplete: Great job! You completed the constellation:
kids.goodScore: Good job! You know a lot about space!
kids.tryAgainMessage: Keep learning about space and try again!

loader.loadingWait: This might take a few seconds.

ebooks.title: NASA E-books
ebooks.subtitle: Download official NASA books and explore the cosmos from your device

subscription.upgradeMsg: Want to upgrade your subscription? Choose a higher plan and pay only the difference.
